nodes.text: A likelihood-based analysis of vector autoregressive (VAR) models provides a coherent framework to model, test and interpret cointegration among nonstationary economic time series
Cointegration: nonstationary processes can have linear combinations that are stationary; the number of independent stationary combinations is the cointegration rank

Three parametric formulations to model cointegration: regression residual approach (Engle-Granger), autoregressive error-correction VAR (Johansen), and unobserved components (state-space/Kalman) formulations

The VAR error correction model used: Delta x_t = alpha (beta' x_{t-1} + Upsilon D_t) + sum_{i=1}^{k-1} Gamma_i Delta x_{t-i} + Phi d_t + epsilon_t, with alpha and beta p x r matrices and epsilon_t iid(0, Omega)

Granger Representation Theorem: under the I(1) condition, the VAR error-correction model has a moving-average representation showing r stationary cointegrating relations beta' x_t and p-r stochastic trends C sum_{i=1}^t epsilon_i; formula C = beta_perp (alpha_perp' Gamma beta_perp)^{-1} alpha_perp'

I(1) condition: characteristic roots outside unit circle except z=1 and rank condition |alpha_perp' Gamma beta_perp| != 0 are required to ensure solutions are cointegrated I(1) processes and avoid I(2) or higher

Likelihood estimation and inference via reduced rank regression (RRR): maximum likelihood estimation of VAR cointegration parameters reduces to RRR on residuals with eigenvalue problem and yields LR test statistic -T sum_{i=r+1}^p log(1-lambda_i) for cointegration rank

Asymptotic distribution of the rank (likelihood ratio) test depends on number of common trends p-r and deterministic terms: limit is functional of Brownian motion (Dickey-Fuller family); tables or simulation required for critical values

Asymptotic distribution of estimators: estimator of beta (cointegrating vectors) is mixed Gaussian (rate T), estimators of alpha and short-run parameters are asymptotically Gaussian and asymptotically independent of beta estimate; Wald and LR tests on beta are asymptotically chi-square under identification

Interpretation of cointegrating coefficients: beta coefficients represent long-run relations; a coefficient can be interpreted as the long-run effect of a change in one variable on another holding other variables fixed in the long run via the C and Gamma mappings

Economic hypotheses map to testable restrictions: examples include purchasing power parity, present value relations, interest parity and rational expectations which impose linear restrictions on beta and/or alpha and short-run dynamics

Practical model checking and limitations: Gaussian likelihood methods require checking lag length, residual normality, autocorrelation, heteroscedasticity and parameter constancy; autocorrelation and parameter breaks can invalidate asymptotic results

Extensions and open problems: (1) I(2) and higher integration require extended parametrizations and nonstandard asymptotics; (2) nonlinear cointegration and regime changes need further theory; (3) small-sample corrections and integration with economic theory remain important research tasks
